newsitem.title: CHINA: Yuan ends down at two-week low against US dollar.
newsitem.headline: Yuan ends down at two-week low against US dollar.

text.p: The Chinese yuan closed down at a two-week low of 8.2955 against the U.S. dollar in Shanghai on Monday due to profit-taking, traders said.
The close was down from 8.2944 last Friday and the lowest close since April 15 when the yuan ended at 8.2959.
The weighted average price on Friday was 8.2943.
Dealers said the yuan failed to maintain its upward trend on Friday after rises earlier last week, which caused profit-taking on Monday and forced it to fall for most of the session.

The yuan opened higher at an intraday high of 8.2940 and consolidated for most of the session, hitting a low of 8.2958 late in trading, traders said. Trading was active with most business done at 8.2950, they said.
One dealer said Friday's fall made traders cautious and some sold the local currency to take profits.
"The yuan moved mostly above the key 8.2950 level last week and it needed a technical correction," he added.
A second dealer said pro-yuan sentiment was strong despite the fall on Monday and that he expected it to rebound shortly.
"The yuan will fall sharply," he said. "A brief movement around the 8.2950 will be good for further rises."
Dealers said they expected the yuan to rise slightly on Tuesday.
The market will close for the Labour Day holiday from Thursday to Saturday, resuming on Sunday, an exchange official said.
The yuan closed up at 6.5410 from 6.5625 against 100 Japanese yen and down at 1.0713 from 1.0700 against the Hong Kong dollar.
